title: How to Make Dal Bati

steps.headline: Whisk the flour, semolina, caraway, baking powder, and salt.
steps.description: Put 2 cups (240 g) of whole-wheat flour into a mixing bowl and add 1 cup (167 g) of semolina (sooji/rava) along with 1 teaspoon (2 g) of caraway seeds (carom seeds), 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking powder, and salt according to your taste. Whisk the dry ingredients until they're combined. If you like, you can make the bati dough in a food processor.

steps.headline: Mix in ghee and water to form a stiff dough.
steps.description: Spoon 1/2 cup (110 g) of ghee into the mixing bowl and use your hands to rub it into the dry ingredients. Then drizzle a little water into the bowl and keep mixing until a rough dough starts to pull away from the sides of the bowl.Tip: Add just a little water at a time so the dough doesn't become too sticky. If the dough is too sticky, it will be difficult to shape into balls.

steps.headline: Rest the bati dough for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Knead the dough into a smooth, stiff ball and place it back into the mixing bowl. Lay a damp kitchen towel or clean cloth over the bowl and set the dough aside to rest for 20 minutes. The gluten in the flour will relax as it rests. This will make the bati tender instead of tough.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and divide the dough portions.
steps.description: Transfer the bati dough to a work surface and divide it into 12 to 15 equal portions that are about the size of a lemon. Then roll each portion between your palms to make balls. For a classic bati design, mark an X on each ball using a butter knife. The ghee in the dough will prevent the dough from sticking to your hands.

steps.headline: Bake the batis for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the batis on a rimmed baking sheet and put them in the preheated oven. Bake the batis until they're dry and browned on both sides. Turn them halfway through the cooking time so they bake evenly. Since the batis won't expand in size, you can place them right next to each other on the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Remove the batis from the oven.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and place the batis aside to cool while you make the dal and tadka. For an extra-rich flavor, you can dip the batis in extra ghee. If you like, crush a few of the cooled batis and stir in more ghee with jaggery. You can serve this churma alongside the dal and bati.

steps.headline: Soak the dal for 2 hours.
steps.description: Put 1/4 cup (50 g) of green moong dal, 1/4 cup (50 g) of black urad dal, and 1/4 cup (50 g) of chana dal into a bowl. Pour in enough water to cover the dal by 2 inches (5.1 cm). Leave the dal to soak for at least 2 hours or overnight.

steps.headline: Mince the onion, ginger, and garlic.
steps.description: Peel 1 onion and use a chef's knife to mince it. Scoot it to the side of your cutting board and peel about 1 inch (2.5 cm) of fresh ginger. Finely chop the ginger along with 3 cloves of peeled garlic. It's important to use fresh ginger and garlic so your dal has intense flavor.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion, ginger, and garlic in ghee for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Put 1 teaspoon (4 g) of ghee into a stovetop pressure cooker and turn it on to medium heat. Then add the minced onion, ginger, and garlic. Stir and cook the mixture until the onion softens a little.

steps.headline: Add the chili, tomato, bay, cinnamon, turmeric, and garam masala.
steps.description: Chop 1 tomato and cut a slit lengthwise through 1 green chili. Add these to the pressure cooker along with 1 bay leaf (tej patta), 1 cinnamon stick (dalchini), 1 teaspoon (2 g) of turmeric powder (haldi), and 1 teaspoon (2 g) of garam masala powder. Stir to combine the mixture. Stir in salt according to your taste.

steps.headline: Stir in the dal along with 2 ⁄2 cups (590 ml) of the soaking liquid.
steps.description: Once the seasonings are incorporated, add the soaked dal and some of its soaking liquid. The dal will continue to absorb liquid as it pressure cooks.

steps.headline: Seal and pressure cook the dal for about 20 minutes.
steps.description: Add more water as needed and then secure the lid on the pressure cooker. Pressure cook the dal until the dal softens and becomes fragrant.Tip: If you're counting whistles to cook the dal, listen for 2 or 3 whistles. Then turn the heat to low and simmer the dal for 10 minutes before you turn off the heat. Ensure that the dal is covered by 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water before you put the lid on the pressure cooker.

steps.headline: Open the pressure cooker and garnish the dal with cilantro.
steps.description: Release the pressure from the cooker and carefully remove the lid. Stir the dal and check that it's completely soft. Then chop 5 sprigs of fresh cilantro and sprinkle it on top. Taste the dal and add more salt or seasonings according to your taste.

parts.name: Making the Tadka and Serving Dal Bati

steps.headline: Heat ghee in a skillet along with cumin seeds and dry red chilies.
steps.description: Put 1 teaspoon (4 g) of ghee into a skillet and turn the burner to medium-high. Stir in 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cumin seeds (jeera) and 2 dry red chilies that you've snapped in half.Did You Know? The ghee won't burn because it has a very high smoke point.

steps.headline: Stir and cook the tadka for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Keep stirring as the cumin seeds begin to crackle in the skillet. Turn off the burner once the cumin seeds begin to brown. The tadka should smell fragrant and spicy.

steps.headline: Pour the tadka over the dal and serve it with the batis.
steps.description: Place 1 to 2 batis in a serving bowl and spoon dal over them. If you prefer, put the dal next to the batis. Then drizzle a little of the tadka over the dal and serve it immediately. Refrigerate the leftover dal in an airtight container for up to 3 to 4 days. Store the leftover batis in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 days.
